sections.heading: What is Imperative Form?
sections.content:
Imperative form (命令形) is the direct command form. It's very strong and blunt, rarely used in polite conversation.

食べろ！(tabero!) - Eat! 行け！(ike!) - Go! しろ！(shiro!) - Do it!

Warning: Very rough! Use carefully!

children.heading: 1. Emergency Situations
children.content: 逃げろ！ "Run!" / "Escape!" 止まれ！ "Stop!" 助けを呼べ！ "Call for help!"

children.heading: 2. Military/Sports Commands
children.content: 走れ！ "Run!" 頑張れ！ "Do your best!" / "Go for it!" 行け！ "Go!"

children.heading: 3. Very Casual (Male Speech)
children.content: 早く来い！ "Come quickly!" ちょっと待て "Wait a sec"

children.heading: 4. Written Commands (Signs)
children.content: 止まれ (road sign) "Stop" 押せ (on doors/buttons) "Push" 引け (on doors) "Pull"

children.heading: Ichidan Verbs
children.content:
Drop る , add ろ or よ :

食べる → 食べろ (tabero) - Eat! 見る → 見ろ (miro) - Look! 寝る → 寝ろ (nero) - Sleep! 起きる → 起きろ (okiro) - Wake up!

Alternative: Add よ instead (more forceful)

食べる → 食べよ 見る → 見よ

children.heading: Godan Verbs
children.content:
Change -u to -e :

書く → 書け (kaku → kake) - Write! kak-u → kak-e 読む → 読め (yomu → yome) - Read! yom-u → yom-e 話す → 話せ (hanasu → hanase) - Speak! hanas-u → hanas-e 買う → 買え (kau → kae) - Buy! ka-u → ka-e 待つ → 待て (matsu → mate) - Wait! mat-u → mat-e 遊ぶ → 遊べ (asobu → asobe) - Play! asob-u → asob-e 帰る → 帰れ (kaeru → kaere) - Go home! kaer-u → kaer-e 泳ぐ → 泳げ (oyogu → oyoge) - Swim! oyog-u → oyog-e 行く → 行け (iku → ike) - Go! ik-u → ik-e

children.heading: Irregular Verbs
children.content: する → しろ (shiro) - Do it! 来る → 来い (こい, koi) - Come!

sections.heading: Complete Conjugation Chart
sections.content: | Dictionary | E-row | Imperative | Meaning | | ---------- | ------- | ---------- | ------- | | 書く | kak-e | 書け | Write! | | 読む | yom-e | 読め | Read! | | 話す | hanas-e | 話せ | Speak! | | 買う | ka-e | 買え | Buy! | | 食べる | tabe | 食べろ | Eat! | | 見る | mi | 見ろ | Look! | | する | - | しろ | Do it! | | 来る | - | 来い | Come! |

sections.heading: Polite Alternatives
sections.content:
DON'T use imperative in polite situations!

Use these instead:

children.heading: ～てください (Please do)
children.content: 食べてください "Please eat" (polite) 座ってください "Please sit" (polite)

children.heading: ～なさい (Softer command)
children.content: 食べなさい "Eat" (parental, teacher → student) 勉強しなさい "Study" (less harsh than imperative)

children.heading: ～て (Casual request)
children.content: ちょっと待って "Wait a sec" (casual but not rude) 見て見て！ "Look, look!" (friendly)

children.heading: Emergency
children.content: 危ない！逃げろ！ "Dangerous! Run!" 止まれ！ "Stop!" 助けて！ "Help!" (te-form, not imperative)

children.heading: Sports/Encouragement
children.content: 頑張れ！ "Do your best!" / "Go for it!" 行け！ "Go!" / "You can do it!" 走れ！ "Run!" 負けるな！ "Don't lose!"

children.heading: Casual Commands (Male)
children.content: 早く来い "Come quickly" 黙れ "Shut up" (very rude!) やれ "Do it" 待て "Wait"

sections.heading: Signs and Written Commands
sections.content: 押せ "Push" (on doors/buttons) 引け "Pull" (on doors) 止まれ "Stop" (traffic sign) 入るな "Do not enter"

children.heading: Mistake 1: Using in Polite Conversation
children.content: Wrong: 食べろ (to stranger/superior) ❌ Right: 食べてください ✓ "Please eat" Imperative is TOO STRONG for normal use!

children.heading: Mistake 2: Wrong E-row Conjugation
children.content: Wrong: 書く → 書くろ ❌ Right: 書く → 書け ✓ Wrong: 読む → 読むろ ❌ Right: 読む → 読め ✓

children.heading: Mistake 3: Using with Superiors
children.content: Wrong: 先生、見ろ！ ❌ Right: 先生、見てください ✓ "Teacher, please look" NEVER use imperative with superiors!

sections.heading: Imperative vs Other Command Forms
sections.content: | Form | Strength | Usage | | ------------------ | ----------- | ---------------- | | 食べろ | Very strong | Emergency/rough | | 食べなさい | Medium | Parents/teachers | | 食べて | Casual | Friends | | 食べてください | Polite | Normal requests | | 食べてくださいませ | Very polite | Customer service |

children.heading: Male Speech
children.content:
More likely to use imperative:

来い！ "Come!" やれ！ "Do it!"

children.heading: Female Speech
children.content:
Rarely uses imperative, prefers:

来て！ "Come!" (te-form) やってよ！ "Do it!" (te-form + yo)

sections.heading: Softening Imperative
sections.content:
Add particles to soften:

食べろよ "Eat" (casual encouragement) 行けよ "Go" (less harsh) 待てって！ "Wait, I said!" (emphatic but less rude)

children.heading: Example 1: Emergency
children.content: A: 火事だ！ "Fire!" B: 早く逃げろ！ "Run quickly!" A: 消防署を呼べ！ "Call the fire department!"

children.heading: Example 2: Sports
children.content: Coach: 走れ！頑張れ！ "Run! Do your best!" Player: はい！ "Yes!" Coach: 諦めるな！最後まで行け！ "Don't give up! Go until the end!"

children.heading: Example 3: Casual Friends (Male)
children.content: A: おい、ちょっと待て "Hey, wait a sec" B: 何？ "What?" A: これ見ろよ "Look at this"

sections.heading: When NOT to Use Imperative
sections.content:
Avoid in:

Normal conversation With strangers With superiors Formal situations Service situations First meetings Professional settings

Use instead:

～てください (polite) ～てくれる？ (casual request) ～なさい (softer command) ～て (casual between friends)

children.heading: 頑張れ！
children.content: 頑張れ！ "Do your best!" / "Go for it!" / "You can do it!" (Most common imperative in daily life - encouraging)

children.heading: 止まれ (Traffic sign)
children.content: 止まれ "Stop" (Standard on stop signs)

sections.heading: Imperative in Anime/Manga
sections.content:
Very common in fiction:

やめろ！ "Stop it!" 黙れ！ "Shut up!" 行け！ "Go!" 来い！ "Come here!"

Note: This is dramatic language, not everyday speech!

sections.heading: Combining with Particles
sections.content: 行けよ "Go!" (encouraging) 食えって！ "Eat, I said!" 見ろよこれ "Look at this" 待てって "Wait!"

sections.heading: Practice Recognition
sections.content:
Can you identify these?

食べろ - Imperative "Eat!" 食べて - Te-form "Eat" (casual request) 食べなさい - Softer command "Eat" 食べてください - Polite "Please eat"

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
✓ Imperative = direct command (very strong) ✓ Godan: -u → -e ✓ Ichidan: -ru → -ro ✓ Very rough, rarely used politely ✓ Common in emergencies and sports ✓ Use ～てください instead normally ✓ More common in male speech ✓ OK for signs and written commands ✓ Never use with superiors

Learn imperative - but use it carefully!
